details.body:
A financial benefit award is an award for a suggestion:

*   relating to an improvement in efficiency
or effectiveness
*   which the employer has decided to adopt
and
*   which the employer reasonably expects will
result in a financial benefit.

The suggestion maximum for a financial benefit award is the
**greater** of:

*   half the financial benefit that the
employer reasonably expects will result from the adoption of the
suggestion in the first year after its adoption, or
*   one tenth of the financial benefit that
the employer reasonably expects to result from its adoption in the
first five years after its adoption,

**subject, in each case, to an over-riding maximum of
£5,000**.

The amount arrived at above is the maximum that the employer

can pay, tax free, in respect of a single suggestion.

See also:

sections.title:
Two or more awards for

same suggestion on same occasion.
sections.body:
Section 322(2) ITEPA 2003 provides a rule for deciding how the
exempt amount relating to a financial benefit award (see
[EIM06630](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM06630)) is to be apportioned if an
employer makes two or more awards for the same suggestion on the
same occasion. This could happen, for example, if a suggestion is
submitted jointly by two or more employees.

The rule is that the exempt amount, called the suggestion
maximum, is to be apportioned between the recipients in the same
proportion as their individual awards bear to the total sum
awarded. See example
[EIM06641](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06641) and example
[EIM06642](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06642).

In cases where the employer makes two or more awards for the
same suggestion on different occasions, see also
[EIM06650](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06650).

sections.title:
Employee making more than

one successful suggestion.
sections.body:
EIM06640 explained how the exempt amount (the “suggestion
maximum”) for a financial benefit award is apportioned when
an employer makes two or more awards for the same suggestion on the
same occasion. There are further rules for deciding how much is
exempt from tax when two or more awards are made, for the same
suggestion, at different times. This could happen if an employer
made an initial award for a promising suggestion followed by a
later award when the suggestion has been fully evaluated.

*   The basic rule is that the total amount
qualifying for exemption in respect of a single suggestion must not
exceed the suggestion maximum calculated in accordance with[EIM06630](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM06630).
*   The suggestion maximum is set against the
earliest award(s) first, applying the rule in[EIM06640](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06640) if awards were made to two or

    more people at the same time.
*   If the suggestion maximum is not

    completely used up against the first award, the balance can be set

    against any later award, and so on (see example
    [EIM06651](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06651)).
*   If a later award is made to two or more

    people at the same time, the balance of the suggestion maximum is

    apportioned between them as described in EIM06640 (see example
    [EIM06652](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06652)).

sections.title:
Employer using scheme to

make non-qualifying awards.
sections.body:
If an employer uses a suggestions scheme to make awards which do
not satisfy the conditions set out in
[EIM06610](/guidance/employment-income-manual/EIM04700#EIM06610) (for example, because the
suggestion was made at a meeting held for the purpose of proposing
suggestions) the award does not qualify for exemption and must be
taxed in full.

However, the making of such awards does not disqualify the
employer’s entire scheme. Other awards that do meet all the
conditions will continue to be exempt, up to the permitted
maximum.
